awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II: Developing a courseware platform that helps students develop self-regulated learning skills
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to develop courseware that will catalyze the use of inclusive, evidence-based teaching and learning practices. Such practices have been empirically shown to improve learning outcomes and retention rates for postsecondary Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) students, particularly those from historically underserved groups: first-generation college attendees, students from racial and ethnic minorities, and students from low-income families. These practices have not been widely adopted because instructors lack the time and resources needed to shift from a lecture-based course to one grounded in evidence-based practices and students struggle to use the evidence-based study strategies that are more effective for college courses. This project helps instructors design and teach inclusive, high-structure courses and helps students develop stronger metacognition and self-regulated learning skills, both of which will lead to more equitable outcomes for students from historically underserved communities. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project aims to create novel courseware that helps students develop self-regulated learning skills and guides instructors to design and teach aligned, high-structure courses. Both of these practices are supported by empirical research. However, these practices are underutilized, not because of a lack of understanding or evidence of their efficacy, but because instructors lack time to design a high-structure course and work one-on-one with students to develop their learning skills. Instructors need a courseware tool to help students effectively reap the known benefits of these practices. Using this courseware platform, instructors and students will benefit from rich sets of actionable learning data that help them adjust their teaching and learning. Research will be conducted — with results disaggregated by race, ethnicity, gender, socioeconomic status, and first-generation status — to determine whether the courseware improves students’ self-regulated learning skills and instructors’ use of evidence-based teaching practices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project supported the development of a novel courseware platform that guides instructors to design and teach high-structure courses and enhances students’ self-regulated learning skills. 

The Codon Learning platform guides an instructor to design a high-structure course by building frequent assignments that engage students before class, after class, and when studying, providing them with automatic, response-specific feedback. Research shows highly structured courses, those with daily and weekly opportunities for practice and feedback, disproportionately improve outcomes for students from underserved groups.

Every assessment question in a Codon course is aligned to lesson-level learning objectives (LOs) assigned by the instructor. LOs are concise, specific, and measurable statements that identify the skills and knowledge that students are expected to attain. The Codon platform makes the LOs transparent to students, helping instructors explicitly convey their expectations. The objective is to counteract the negative impact of the "hidden curriculum," a phenomenon that often marginalizes first-generation and historically underserved students that may arrive in college underprepared.

Codon Learning operationalizes LOs to support students in a way that no other platform on the market does. The Codon Study Path provides a way for students to visualize and organize the LOs that they are responsible for learning and enables them to easily identify LOs that they struggled with. The Study Path gives students additional opportunities to test themselves and track their progress. Students using the platform report that the Study Path helps them study more efficiently and encourages them to return to topics that they struggled with, a hallmark of self-regulated learning skill development. 

Alignment between LOs and assessment items is associated with increased student success on exams. Indeed, data show that students who complete all of the study assignments in the Codon Learning platform scored 11 points higher on their final grade, controlling for prior knowledge. The hope is that this boost in early “gateway” courses will help retain students that would have otherwise been excluded from future STEM courses. In the two and a half years since the launch of the Codon Learning platform, it has been implemented by more than 200 instructors in over 240 courses, reaching more than 30,000 students!
